newsitem.title: SWEDEN: FORECAST - Analysts do not see Swedish repo cut Tues.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - Analysts do not see Swedish repo cut Tues.

text.p: Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, will not lower its key interest rate, the repo, at its weekly tender on Tuesday, according to seven of 12 economists polled by Reuters.
The weak crown was seen as the main reason keeping the repo at 4.10 percent.
"The crown is too volatile and too weak. Everything else is supportive of a cut, but I don't think it will be now," said Bjorn Englund, Unibank Markets economist.
At the end of January, Riksbank deputy governor Lars Heikensten said information about the economy and price development was giving a more positive picture of inflation in 1997.
However, he said the currency was somewhat weaker than the bank had expected.
The Trade Currency Weighted (TCW) index, used to measure the value of the crown against other currencies, has risen to a nominal 120.77.
The Riksbank earlier said a reasonable level for the TCW-index was between 109 to 118, with a preference for the lower end of this range.
The index peaked at a nominal 122.57 on February 6 and is currently at 119.19.
Most economists also expected the Riksbank to wait and see the Prospera inflation forecast survey, due on Wednesday. The bank commissions the survey.
Some expected the Riksbank to delay a repo rate cut until after its inflation report on March 20.
Three of the economists surveyed thought there was a 50/50 chance the Riksbank would lower the repo rate on Tuesday and two expected a cut.
The repo rate, which is the bank's key tool for controlling money market liquidity, was last lowered on December 17, the same day as the Riksbank's last inflation report.
Last year, the repo rate was cut 25 times, taking it down to its current 4.10 percent fom 8.91 percent.

Economists included in the poll were from Carnegie, Den Danske, Hagstromer & Qviberg, Handelsbanken, HSBC Midland, JP Morgan, Nordbanken, PaineWebber, Salomon Brothers, S-E-Banken, Swebank and Unibank Markets.
